content: As of late January 2026, the OpenClaw skills system contains over 700 community abilities (skills).

payload.content: ClawHub is defined as a public skill registry for OpenClaw, where all skills are explicitly free, public, open, and visible for sharing and reuse.

content: ClawHub is defined as a public skill registry for OpenClaw, where all skills are explicitly free, public, open, and visible for sharing and reuse.

payload.content: ClawHub's official documentation emphasizes public browsing of skills, versioned bundles, and moderation tools, without mentioning built-in monetization, licensing, or commerce features.

name: ClawHub's official documentation emphasizes public browsing of skills, versioned
content: ClawHub's official documentation emphasizes public browsing of skills, versioned bundles, and moderation tools, without mentioning built-in monetization, licensing, or commerce features.

payload.content: Any paywalling of OpenClaw skills appears to occur outside of the ClawHub registry (e.g., via private distributions, Patreon, or 'DM me for key' models) rather than as a first-class feature of ClawHub itself, as the registry is positioned as 'no gatekeeping, just signal' and skills are explicitly public and open.

name: Any paywalling of OpenClaw skills appears to occur outside of the ClawHub regist
content: Any paywalling of OpenClaw skills appears to occur outside of the ClawHub registry (e.g., via private distributions, Patreon, or 'DM me for key' models) rather than as a first-class feature of ClawHub itself, as the registry is positioned as 'no gatekeeping, just signal' and skills are explicitly public and open.

payload.content: ClawHub currently functions as a free, open registry hosting approximately 700+ skills, without an official paywall layer; any paywalled skills are community-run and off-platform.

name: ClawHub currently functions as a free, open registry hosting approximately 700+
content: ClawHub currently functions as a free, open registry hosting approximately 700+ skills, without an official paywall layer; any paywalled skills are community-run and off-platform.

content: ClawHub documentation describes stars, comments, tags, and search as mechanisms for skill discovery and feedback, but it does not provide a canonical 'top 10' list based on installs.

content: A Reddit thread indicates that download ranking is visible within the ClawHub registry, implying that some skills are measurably more popular than others.

content: A YouTube walkthrough suggests that skills enabling general-purpose automation, cron/heartbeat functionality, and multi-platform integration are commonly recommended within the OpenClaw/Clawdbot skills system.

content: A precise 'top 10 most-installed' list for ClawHub skills cannot be confirmed from publicly available material, although the existence of popularity ranking is implied.

payload.content: A LocalLLaMA post describes a simulated backdoor skill created to explore supply-chain risks associated with the most-downloaded ClawdHub skill, indicating community awareness and probing of security vulnerabilities.

name: A LocalLLaMA post describes a simulated backdoor skill created to explore supply
content: A LocalLLaMA post describes a simulated backdoor skill created to explore supply-chain risks associated with the most-downloaded ClawdHub skill, indicating community awareness and probing of security vulnerabilities.

payload.content: The threat model for OpenClaw skills is that they run locally on the user's hardware, meaning the primary risk is installing malicious code from ClawHub (acting like npm/registry) rather than remote execution on a shared SaaS.

name: The threat model for OpenClaw skills is that they run locally on the user's hard
content: The threat model for OpenClaw skills is that they run locally on the user's hardware, meaning the primary risk is installing malicious code from ClawHub (acting like npm/registry) rather than remote execution on a shared SaaS.

payload.content: ClawHub documentation mentions 'moderation hooks for approvals and audits,' including the ability to hide, unhide, delete, or ban skills, suggesting a reactive security and trust system for reported abusive or unsafe skills.

name: ClawHub documentation mentions 'moderation hooks for approvals and audits,' incl
content: ClawHub documentation mentions 'moderation hooks for approvals and audits,' including the ability to hide, unhide, delete, or ban skills, suggesting a reactive security and trust system for reported abusive or unsafe skills.

payload.content: No major real-world security compromises (e.g., high-impact malware incidents) affecting many users are documented in the surfaced material for OpenClaw; the prominent security example is a simulated backdoor research post.

name: No major real-world security compromises (e.g., high-impact malware incidents) a
content: No major real-world security compromises (e.g., high-impact malware incidents) affecting many users are documented in the surfaced material for OpenClaw; the prominent security example is a simulated backdoor research post.

payload.content: ClawHub describes skills as 'versioned bundles of files' with `SKILL.md` and metadata, referencing 'AgentSkills bundles' on its homepage and positioning itself as a registry that understands and indexes these bundles.

name: ClawHub describes skills as 'versioned bundles of files' with `SKILL.md` and met
content: ClawHub describes skills as 'versioned bundles of files' with `SKILL.md` and metadata, referencing 'AgentSkills bundles' on its homepage and positioning itself as a registry that understands and indexes these bundles.

payload.content: The surfaced documentation and marketing copy do not indicate that the underlying AgentSkills specification has been forked away from Anthropic; it is still described as an Anthropic-originated concept adopted by OpenClaw.

name: The surfaced documentation and marketing copy do not indicate that the underlyin
content: The surfaced documentation and marketing copy do not indicate that the underlying AgentSkills specification has been forked away from Anthropic; it is still described as an Anthropic-originated concept adopted by OpenClaw.

payload.content: Herbert Yang is building multi-model agent architectures on OpenClaw, using Claude Sonnet-4 for orchestration and DeepSeek V3 for sub-agents.

name: Herbert Yang is building multi-model agent architectures on OpenClaw, using Clau
content: Herbert Yang is building multi-model agent architectures on OpenClaw, using Claude Sonnet-4 for orchestration and DeepSeek V3 for sub-agents.

payload.content: Herbert Yang's work includes orchestration agents that route tasks to different models and sub-agents running cheaper or specialized models, aligning with 'council' or parallel research patterns.

name: Herbert Yang's work includes orchestration agents that route tasks to different
content: Herbert Yang's work includes orchestration agents that route tasks to different models and sub-agents running cheaper or specialized models, aligning with 'council' or parallel research patterns.

payload.content: Herbert Yang is heavily utilizing automation, including cron jobs and ghost jobs across restarts, within his OpenClaw deployments as part of a broader multi-agent automation setup.

name: Herbert Yang is heavily utilizing automation, including cron jobs and ghost jobs
content: Herbert Yang is heavily utilizing automation, including cron jobs and ghost jobs across restarts, within his OpenClaw deployments as part of a broader multi-agent automation setup.

payload.content: When cron jobs are deleted in OpenClaw, they can persist after a gateway restart because recovery logic prioritizes orphaned `.tmp` files over `jobs.json`, leading to "ghost cron jobs."

name: When cron jobs are deleted in OpenClaw, they can persist after a gateway restart
content: When cron jobs are deleted in OpenClaw, they can persist after a gateway restart because recovery logic prioritizes orphaned `.tmp` files over `jobs.json`, leading to "ghost cron jobs."

payload.content: OpenClaw's ClawHub provides discovery for skills, while the skills themselves execute locally on the user's hardware, enabling complex local compositions including chaining command-line tools and multiple models.

name: OpenClaw's ClawHub provides discovery for skills, while the skills themselves ex
content: OpenClaw's ClawHub provides discovery for skills, while the skills themselves execute locally on the user's hardware, enabling complex local compositions including chaining command-line tools and multiple models.

payload.content: Common patterns in OpenClaw include an orchestrator agent (e.g., Claude Sonnet-4) coordinating sub-agents on cheaper/specialized models, cron-driven background agents for long-running workflows, and skill composition chaining shell tools, web search, and messaging channels into multi-step pipelines.

name: Common patterns in OpenClaw include an orchestrator agent (e.g., Claude Sonnet-4
content: Common patterns in OpenClaw include an orchestrator agent (e.g., Claude Sonnet-4) coordinating sub-agents on cheaper/specialized models, cron-driven background agents for long-running workflows, and skill composition chaining shell tools, web search, and messaging channels into multi-step pipelines.

payload.content: A bug in `@openclaw sessions_spawn` causes the `model` parameter to be silently ignored and fall back to a default when extra parameters like `agentId` are passed.

name: A bug in `@openclaw sessions_spawn` causes the `model` parameter to be silently
content: A bug in `@openclaw sessions_spawn` causes the `model` parameter to be silently ignored and fall back to a default when extra parameters like `agentId` are passed.

payload.content: The `sessions_spawn` bug led a user to mistakenly believe cost optimization was working with DeepSeek V3, while everything was actually running on a more expensive default model.

name: The `sessions_spawn` bug led a user to mistakenly believe cost optimization was
content: The `sessions_spawn` bug led a user to mistakenly believe cost optimization was working with DeepSeek V3, while everything was actually running on a more expensive default model.

payload.content: To work around the `@openclaw sessions_spawn` bug, only pass the core three parameters: `model`, `label`, and `task`, omitting all other parameters, especially `agentId`.

name: To work around the `@openclaw sessions_spawn` bug, only pass the core three para
content: To work around the `@openclaw sessions_spawn` bug, only pass the core three parameters: `model`, `label`, and `task`, omitting all other parameters, especially `agentId`.

payload.content: The bug regarding `sessions_spawn` and `agentId` has been filed as GitHub issue `openclaw/openclaw/issues/6817`, but its fix status is unknown as of February 1, 2026.

name: The bug regarding `sessions_spawn` and `agentId` has been filed as GitHub issue
content: The bug regarding `sessions_spawn` and `agentId` has been filed as GitHub issue `openclaw/openclaw/issues/6817`, but its fix status is unknown as of February 1, 2026.

content: In OpenClaw, "conversational AI" appears to be a descriptive concept for community patterns like orchestrator and sub-agents in a chat-like environment, rather than an official, documented feature.

content: There is no formal, named "superintelligent path" pattern documented in OpenClaw; it is an aspirational framing used in some community discussions rather than an official architectural blueprint.
